name: Deathmatch Classic
description: Enjoy fast-paced multiplayer gaming with Deathmatch Classic (a.k.a. DMC). Valve's tribute to the work of id software, DMC invites players to grab their rocket launchers and put their reflexes to the test in a collection of futuristic settings.
minimum_requirements: 500 mhz processor, 96mb ram, 16mb video card, Windows XP, Mouse, Keyboard, Internet Connection Recommended: 800 mhz processor, 128mb ram, 32mb+ video card, Windows XP, Mouse, Keyboard, Internet Connection

reviews.review_text: Buy this game and join the community of one
Multiplayer Quake for Half-Life. Nice!

Deathmatch Classic was a mod for Half-Life created by Valve software alongside others like Team Fortress Classic and Day of Defeat. Unfortunately it was never as popular as some of the others and quietly faded back into obscurity.  DMC is essentially a remake of the multiplayer component of Quake 1 using Half-Life's particular GoldSrc engine. Including remade versions of Quake 1's various weapons, such as the nailgun, super shotgun and rocket launcher. It uses a lot of Half-life's assets like multiplayer models, textures and sprites. And at the same time attempts to mimic Quake's physics. Allowing players to also bunnyhop and strafejump. They also remade several of Quake 1's deathmatch maps and included them with the game.  Now all of this was great. Although Deathmatch Classic released at around the same time as Quake 3 and Unreal Tournament. As a result the community didn't really gravitate towards it as much as Valve would have liked, seeing it as a little outdated and more of a novelty.   Playing it today you can see some general upsides to Deathmatch Classic. It uses Steam's server browser and has mods for bots. So it is rather easy to setup a game of classic Quake deathmatch with someone online. But the playerbase is extinct, and as a result it's just another relic in Valve's catalogue
Vintage, timeless fun. Not many people play it nowadays, but enough do to play some good rounds.

I really miss this game. I wish there were some people that still played this. However the grapple mod really killed this game.   I recommend it but it is dead so I highly recommend for a LAN party or a group of friends online.

This game is now dead, meaning only a small handful of people play this game anymore. According to  Steam Charts  [steamcharts.com] , only around two - seven people play this game at the same time.  Unless you have at least five friends who also own and want to play this game, your chances of playing with others is very minimal.

If you are a LAN party enthusiast, I would recommend this as an easy-to-set-up alternative to Quake 1 Deathmatch. Don't buy it for anything else though. As many 'Deathmatch Classic Revival' Steam groups there may be, they amount to nothing and unfortunately this game will remain dead.

An affectionate retraux of Quake 1's deathmatches in the GoldSrc engine.

Much to my personal dismay, Deathmatch Classic has no reason to be recommended. Deathmatch Classic is the original QuakeWorld, but in the GoldSrc (Half-life 1, Counter strike 1.6) engine, most of the maps are great redesigns of Quake's deathmatch maps that still impress me despite its age (I have a thing for castles/churches with compressed jpegs for skyboxes), However not only is the gameplay slower due to its engine, but its playerbase is as dead as Ricochet's. Deathmatch Classic was clearly not meant to be a best-seller but a shoutout to id software and their breakthrough in PC gaming in terms of multiplayer thanks to QuakeWorld and Doom deathmatch.  If you want the Deathmatch Classic experience, save your five bucks, go download Quake Live, and play it until bethesda decides to demand subscription money for every time you push a button mid-game.

A port of the original Quake's deathmatch to GoldSrc, DMC brings back nostalgia to my earliest days in PC gaming. Several exploits are fixed -- especially the skybox exploit in dm2 -- and supports far better graphics settings than the original. It does NOT have any of the graphical features in newer Quake engines, but who needs those?
